This includes, but is not limited to, the warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose, and non-infringement. To find out more about the false positives, review the following resources: https://blog.malwarebytes.com/detections/pup-optional-bitcoinminer/ https://www.kaspersky.com/blog/not-a-virus/18015/ # IMPORTANT SECURITY/PRIVACY UPDATE [Version 0.5.9](https://github.com/VerusCoin/VerusCoin/releases/tag/v0.5.9) incorporated a fix for the Zcash protocol issue described in: https://z.cash/support/security/announcements/security-announcement-2019-09-24/Updating to v0.5.9 or more recent version is considered CRITICAL, not mandatory. What should I do if my antivirus software flags the Verus software as "not-a-virus" or "PUP"?
These warnings are likely false positives, indicating that the software is mining software. You can review the Verus documentation and support resources to learn more about these false positives.

Is it mandatory to update to Verus version 0.5.9 or later?
No, it is not mandatory, but it is considered CRITICAL. Updating to version 0.5.9 or later is highly recommended, as it fixes a security issue related to the Zcash protocol.

What should I do if I have last launched VRSCTEST from a version prior to 0.5.9 on Linux?

You should delete the following directories before running the new update:
```
~/.komodo/VRSCTEST
~/.verustest
```
This is necessary because the testnet was deleted and relaunched on the 0.5.9 release.
